_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The purpose of this document is to describe the process, and demonstrate and evidence that Advanced Green Innovations ("AGI") has: 1) conducted the necessary safety reviews and analysis of potential toxic, fire and explosion hazards related to its business operations; and; 2) implemented the operational safety procedures and safety programs required to comply with the requirements of PHA, RMP, PSM and HAZOP. 



Background.

    

Associated flare gas ("AFG"), or associated gas, is a form of natural gas found with deposits of petroleum, either dissolved in oil or as a free "gas cap" above the oil in the reservoir. AFG is often released as a waste product from the petroleum and/or natural gas extraction process and is combusted in gas flares due to the remote location of many gas fields or oil fields. 



The quality, concentration and content of AFG from oil and gas wells varies significantly from field to field, and well to well. As a result, while highly energetic, AFG is not a consistent uniform fuel that can be used in standardized natural gas engines for power production (i.e., a genset).  However, AGI has developed a solution to this problem.



AGI's Associated Gas Conditioning System (the "AGI AGCS") uses gas reforming technology to convert larger hydrocarbon molecules into methane. The solution developed by AGI is to modify the unit energy content of the raw AFG to a consistent fuel that can be used to operate standard off the shelf natural gas engine gensets. The AGI AGCS uses a process that reforms the heavier liquid fuels leaving lighter hydrocarbons that contain consistent mixture of methane and hydrogen.



The AGI AGCS Process Description.



The AGI AGCS consists of two major process units: (i) a common skid; and (ii) a process skid. 



The common skid consists of a water supply system that provides steam to the unit, and a sulfur removal unit. The incoming gas stream requires the removal of sulfur and other toxic chemicals/compounds. The sulfur remova

l system filters impurities from the incoming AFG to protect the reactor catalyst from premature failure. The filter system has a pressure vessel and media to reduce incoming H2S below 1 ppm. In addition to the H2S removal, the filter system uses a polishing filtration bed to trap benzene, toluene, ethylbenzene, xylenes and other organic sulfides in the flare gas.



The process skid reforms AFG into methane. Components of the process skid include a superheater, heat exchangers, a heavy hydrocarbon reactor ("HHR"), a synthetic natural gas reactor ("SNG"), burner/blowers, mechanical and electronic controls. The process skid electronics control the components on the skid, which are monitored and controlled by the master control on the common skid.



The process skid receives dry steam at 140⁰C (about 285⁰F) from the boiler. The steam is piped to the superheater where it is metered and mixed with pretreated AFG and heated to 500⁰C (about 930⁰F). This steam/gas blend enters the HHR to reform the heavy hydrocarbon chains into a mixture of methane, methyl group molecules, hydrogen and carbon monoxide (CO). The gas mixture is cooled and then transferred to the SNG. The SNG completes the creation of methane molecules, along with small amounts carbon dioxide (CO2) and water. Water is condensed from the SNG output gas, recovered, and returned for re-use in the process. 



The output gas is then returned to the common skid, which removes any excess moisture from the output gas and controls the input gas and steam feed based upon output demands and methane content of the output gas.



Peripheral to this process is an 18,000 gallon natural gas liquids (NGL) storage tank that will be used to store butane and propane which can be used to run through the system when it isn't experiencing a significant load. This avoids the need to turndown the unit. During initial testing, this tank will serve as the main feed for the unit. Prior to the development of the

latest iteration of the unit, there was no inventory of flammable liquids on site, and hence the RMP regulations hadn't been triggered until now.



HAZOP Methodology & Results.



AGI conducted a HAZOP study in connection with the AGI AGCS in order to identify potential hazards and operability safety problems. The process involves investigating how the AGI AGCS could potentially deviate from its design intent. The prime objective for the HAZOP study is problem identification. A process is divided into smaller subsystems called nodes, and then guide words are used to consider deviations from the design intent. 



The purpose of this HAZOP study was to provide an additional layer of safety review over systems in the AGI AGCS unit that contain materials that are flammable, high pressure, or high temperature. This study included a safety review of:  i) the pipes and components that contain, process, and dispose of the AFG; ii) the pipes and components that handle steam (from the boiler outlet); and iii) the pipes and components that handle pressurized nitrogen. 



The AGI HAZOP team included a leader, scribe, and representatives from production and operations, electrical and instrumentation, process design, mechanical, and safety. The HAZOP process was divided into 20 nodes, and required over 200 man hours to complete. A total of 96 recommendations resulted from the HAZOP study. The nodes, guide words, findings, recommended actions, and date of completion are all available for review.

Emergency Response Plan



In addition to the HAZOP, the site has an emergency response plan. I am pasting it below, although tables and photographs do not come through in this format.

EMERGENCY REPORTING AND EVACUATION PROCEDURES



Types of emergencies to be reported by site personnel are:



?    MEDICAL



?    FIRE / EXPLOSION



?    SEVERE WEATHER



?    BOMB THREAT

(e.g., terrorist attack/hostage taking)

 

MEDICAL EMERGENCY



1.    A person trained in First Aid will assess the situation and determine if a medical emergency exists.  

o    If so, they will call move to 2. below

o    If not, they will move the person to a clean dry place preferably out of the elements and treat them.  

o    If needed an incident report will be filled out.  



2.    Call medical emergency phone number (check applicable):

√    Paramedics                                        

√    Ambulance                                          

√    Fire Department                                    

√    Police                                                     

Provide the following information:

a.  Nature of medical emergency,

b.  Location of the emergency (address, building, room number),             and

c.  Your name and phone number from which you are calling.



3.    Assess your current environment.  Do not move victim unless absolutely necessary.



4.    Call the personnel trained in CPR and First Aid to provide the required assistance prior to the arrival of the professional medical help: 



o    (Note:  AGI will always have at least (1) person on site trained in First Aid)



5.    If personnel trained in First Aid are not available, as a minimum, attempt to provide the following assistance:

o    Stop the bleeding with firm pressure on the wounds (note: avoid contact with blood or other bodily fluids).

o    Clear the air passages using the Heimlich Maneuver in case of choking.



6.    In case of rendering assistance to personnel exposed to hazardous materials, consult the Safety Data Sheet (SDS) and wear the appropriate personal protective equipment.  Attempt first aid ONLY if trained and qualified.



 

FIRE EMERGENCY/EXPLOSION

When fire is discovered:

?    Activate the nearest fire alarm (if installed)

?    Notify the local Fire Department by calling  

?    911 or Brazos County Fire Dept 979-361-3888 

?    If the fire alarm is not available, notify the site personnel about the fire emergency by the following means (check applicable):



 

√Voice Communication

  √Phone Paging

                             

 

Fight the fire ONLY if:

?    The Fire Department has been notified.

?    The fire is small and is not spreading to other areas.

?    Escaping the area is possible by backing up to the nearest exit.

?    The fire extinguisher is in working condition and personnel are trained to use it.



Upon being notified about the fire emergency, occupants must:

?    Leave the building/area using the designated escape routes.

?    Assemble in the designated area (specify location):                                    

?    Remain outside until the competent authority

(Designated Official or designee) announces that it is safe to reenter.



Designated Official, Emergency Coordinator or supervisors must (underline one):

?    Disconnect utilities and equipment unless doing so jeopardizes his/her safety.

?    Coordinate an orderly evacuation of personnel.

?    Perform an accurate head count of personnel reported to the designated area.

?    Determine a rescue method to locate missing personnel.

?    Provide the Fire Department personnel with the necessary information about the facility.

?    Perform assessment and coordinate weather forecast office emergency closing procedures    





 

EXTENDED POWER LOSS



In the event of extended power loss to a facility certain precautionary measures should be taken depending on the geographical location and environment of the facility:



?    Unnecessary electrical equipment and appliances should be turned off in the event that power restoration would surge causing damage to electronics and effecting sensitive equipment.

?    Facilities with freezing temperatures should turn off and drain the following lines in the event of a long-term power loss.    

    Fire sprinkler system

    Standpipes

    Potable water lines

    Toilets

?    Add propylene-glycol to drains to prevent traps from freezing    

?    Equipment that contain fluids that may freeze due to long term exposure to freezing temperatures should be moved to heated areas, drained of liquids, or provided with auxiliary heat sources.



Upon Restoration of heat and power:

?    Electronic equipment should be brought up to ambient temperatures before energizing to prevent condensate from forming on circuitry.

?    Fire and potable water piping should be checked for leaks from freeze damage after the heat has been restored to the facility and water turned back on. 

 

CHEMICAL SPILL



The following are the locations of:



Spill Containment and Security Equipment: for odorant or Diesel Fuel



Personal Protective Equipment (PPE):     Gas Sensors

, Standard PPE on person



SDS:  With person in company truck or on AGI Training Site



When a Large Chemical Spill has occurred:

?    Immediately notify the designated official and Emergency Coordinator.

?    Contain the spill with available equipment (e.g., pads, booms, absorbent powder, etc.).        

?    Secure the area and alert other site personnel.

?    Do not attempt to clean the spill unless trained to do so.

?    Attend to injured personnel and call the medical emergency number, if required.    

?    Call a local spill cleanup company or the Fire Department (if arrangement has been made) to perform a large chemical (e.g., mercury) spill cleanup.



o    Name of Spill Cleanup Company:  ESP Safety Net

o    Phone Number:      Jody LaCoste - 903-952-3404, or

Dusty - 432-517-0387



?    Evacuate buildings/Area as necessary and go to Assembly Point as long as that point does not expose you to hazards (fire, fumes, etc.).

?    Remain at the Assembly point until the designated person has accounted for you and further directed you where to go.  

?    Do not re-enter the area until a competent authority announces it is safe to do  so.  



Designated Official, Emergency Coordinator or supervisors must (underline one):

?    Disconnect utilities and equipment unless doing so jeopardizes his/her safety.

?    Coordinate an orderly evacuation of personnel.

?    Perform an accurate head count of personnel reported to the designated area.

?    Determine a rescue method to locate missing personnel.

?    Provide the Fire Department personnel with the necessary information about the facility.

?    Perform assessment and coordinate weather forecast office emergency closing procedures    

?    Inform proper customer official

?    Inform AGI EH&S Manager





When a Small Chemical Spill has occurred:



?    Notify the Designated Person and/or Supervisor (select one).    

?    If toxic fumes are present, secure the area (with caution tapes or cones) to prevent other personnel from entering.    

?    Deal with the spill in accordance with th

e instructions described in the SDS.    

?    Small spills must be handled in a safe manner, while wearing the proper PPE.

?    Review the general spill cleanup procedures.

?    Inform proper customer official

?    Inform AGI EH&S Manager

SEVERE WEATHER AND NATURAL DISASTERS



Tornado:

?    When a warning is issued by sirens or other means, seek inside shelter. Consider the following:

-     Small interior rooms on the lowest floor and without windows,

-     Hallways on the lowest floor away from doors and windows, and

-     Rooms constructed with reinforced concrete, brick, or block with no windows.        

?    Stay away from outside walls and windows.

?    Use arms to protect head and neck.

?    Remain sheltered until the tornado threat is announced to be over.

Shelter location_____NONE______?  Get to a ditch or low area.  

Earthquake:

?    Stay calm and await instructions from the Emergency Coordinator or the designated official.    

?    Keep away from overhead fixtures, windows, filing cabinets, and electrical power.

?    As

sist people with disabilities in finding a safe place.

?    Evacuate as instructed by the Emergency Coordinator and/or the designated official. 

Flood:

If indoors:

?    Be ready to evacuate as directed by the Emergency Coordinator and/or the designated official.    

?    Follow the recommended primary or secondary evacuation routes.

If outdoors:

?    Climb to high ground and stay there.    

?    Avoid walking or driving through flood water.    

?    If car stalls, abandon it immediately and climb to a higher ground.

Hurricane:

?    The nature of a hurricane provides for more warning than other natural and weather disasters. A hurricane watch issued when a hurricane becomes a threat to a coastal area.  A hurricane warning is issued when hurricane winds of 74 mph or higher, or a combination of dangerously high water and rough seas, are expected in the area within 24 hours.

Once a hurricane watch has been issued:

?    Stay calm and await instructions from the Emergency Coordinator or the designated official.    

?    Moor any boats securely, or move to a safe place if time allows.    

?    Continue to monitor local TV and radio stations for instructions.

?    Move early out of low-lying areas or from the coast, at the request of officials.

 

?    If you are on high ground, away from the coast and plan to stay, secure the building, moving all loose items indoors and boarding up windows and openings.

?    Collect drinking water in appropriate containers.

Once a hurricane warning has been issued:

?    Be ready to evacuate as directed by the Emergency Coordinator and/or the designated official.

?    Leave areas that might be affected by storm tide or stream flooding.

During a hurricane:

?    Remain indoors and consider the following:

-     Small interior rooms on the lowest floor and without windows,

-     Hallways on the lowest floor away from doors and windows, and

-     Rooms constructed with reinforced concrete, brick, or block with no windows. 

Blizzard:

If indoors:

?    Stay calm and await instructions from the

Emergency Coordinator or the designated official.

?    Stay indoors!

?    If there is no heat:

-     Close off unneeded rooms or areas.

-     Stuff towels or rags in cracks under doors.

-    Cover windows at night.

?    Eat and drink.  Food provides the body with energy and heat.  Fluids prevent dehydration.

?    Wear layers of loose-fitting, light-weight, warm clothing, if available.

If outdoors:

?    Find a dry shelter.  Cover all exposed parts of the body.

?    If shelter is not available:

-      Prepare a lean-to, wind break, or snow cave for protection from the wind.

-      Build a fire for heat and to attract attention.  Place rocks around the fire to absorb and reflect heat.

-     Do not eat snow.  It will lower your body temperature.  Melt it first.

If stranded in a car or truck:

?    Stay in the vehicle!    

?    Run the motor about ten minutes each hour.  Open the windows a little for fresh air to avoid carbon monoxide poisoning.  Make sure the exhaust pipe is not blocked.    

?    Make yourself visible to rescuers.

-     Turn on the dome light at night when running the engine.

-     Tie a colored cloth to your antenna or door.

-     Raise the hood after the snow stops falling.

?    Exercise to keep blood circulating and to keep warm.
